style.name: Douro rouge (Portugal)
style.description:
Les vins rouges du Douro vont de légers et fruités à luxuriants et lisses voir à sombres et denses avec des saveurs de fruits noirs matures, à base de plantes et de schistes.

Les vins sont souvent de couleur violette en raison de l'épaississement des peaux due à l'intense la chaleur estivale de la région.

La plupart des meilleurs rouges produits dans la région proviennent des plus grandes maisons productrices de Porto, où les compétences des vignerons remontent à des générations. Les vins ont tendance à être intéressants financièrement pour le moment, mais les coûts augmentent lentement en raison des incroyables mélanges provenant de la région.

La première fois que l'on voit la région du Douro, on se demande toujours, comment peut on produire du vin dans un terrain aussi accidenté. C'est aussi une région incroyablement belle, avec des coteaux couverts de vignobles en terrasse. La plupart des grands vignerons ont également commencé à convertir leurs propriétés en destinations touristiques et en hôtels à vin.

Les raisins utilisés comprennent les Touriga Francesa, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Nacional et Tinta Barroca. Les vignobles plus anciens contiennent encore de nombreuses variétés de vignes moins utilisées, ce qui rend leurs rendements annuels moins prévisibles, mais qui réserve des surprises inattendues donnant des vins uniques et complexes.
style.blurb: Vin rouge du nord du Portugal
interesting_facts: La vallée du Douro est la maison du vin de Porto.
Il existe des preuves dès le 3ème siècle d'après J.-C. de la viticulture dans la région.

Les températures dans la vallée du Douro atteignent souvent plus de 40 C° pendant les mois d'été. Cela donne une couleur encre aux vins rouges, dont la peau est plus épaisse que les raisins des climats plus doux.

top_list.name: Vivino's 2016 Wine Style Awards: Portuguese Douro Red
Vivino's 2017 Wine Style Awards: Portuguese Douro Red
Vivino's 2017 Wine Style Awards: Californian Bordeaux Blend

style.name: Vin blanc d'Italie du Nord
style.description:
Often better known for red varieties, Northern Italy has a number of delicious and drinkable white wines. To know Northern Italian wines is to know the influences of the wines of the countries that border Italy.

Old World wines tend to be far less about fruit-forward  flavors, and more about the effect that the climate, soil, and adjacently growing flora (terroir) have on the grapes during their growth.

The most widely recognizable varietal is Pinot Grigio which is very rustic, medium-bodied, with medium to high acidity. Chardonnay seems to grow anywhere grapes can grow; although Italian varieties are not normally coveted quality.

Gewürztraminer usually makes us think of Germany, but it's also thriving in Northern Italy. The warmer climate imparts a little less sugar and little more acidity than its German cousin.

Then there is Moscato. From the northwest Piedmont region, this wine is sweet and very popular in North America, and comes in both still and sparkling varieties.

Whatever your choice, taking a tour of Italian white wines is an enjoyable experience that you will be thankful you took.
interesting_facts: Plus de vin est produit en Italie que n'importe quel autre pays, et du vin y est fabriqué depuis près de 3000 ans.
Il existe plus de 3000 cépages différents en Italie.
Il y a plus de 2 kilos de raisins dans chaque bouteille de vin italien.

top_list.name: Vivino's 2018 Wine Style Awards: Northern Italy White

style.name: Brunello (Italie)
style.description:
From Tuscany in central Italy, Brunello enjoys a distinction as one of Italy's most favored wines.

Brunello ages well and is great for collecting. The wine is bold, rich, and full-bodied. Red and black fruit assertively grace the nose and palate.

Brunello is made totally from Sangiovese grapes that take on the characteristics of the soil, vegetation and climate of the region in which it is grown.

Layered aromas and velvety tannins complement medium-high acidity. Consider decanting this wine to enjoy its full complexity.

This wine pairs well with big protein ladened dishes. You may also enjoy it with salted cheeses and cured meats. Try to avoid pairing with dishes where the wine would overwhelm flavors, such as leafy greens and subtly seasoned meats.
style.blurb: Vin DOCG sangiovese de Toscane
interesting_facts: L'appellation Brunello compte moins de 10 vignerons dans toute l'Italie. Il y a pourtant des vingtaines de domaines sur une aire géographique très restreinte.
La loi italienne interdit toute intervention visant à modifier la température au cours de la croissance du Brunello.
Le Brunello est fait à partir d'un cépage particulier, le Sangiovese, aussi utilisé pour faire le Chianti.

top_list.name: Vivino's 2017 Wine Style Awards: Californian Cabernet Sauvignon

vintage.name: Château Mouton Rothschild Pauillac (Premier Grand Cru Classé) 2016

style.name: Pauillac
style.description:
Bordeaux Pauillac wines are rich and concentrated, full-bodied reds with grippy tannins, and characteristic notes of cassis, cedar and cigar box spice.

The best examples come from blends with a base of high-quality Cabernet Sauvignon and are often considered the quintessential example of a Bordeaux wine.

Pauillac, in Bordeaux's Left Bank Médoc region, boasts well-draining gravel soils, which in turn translates to higher quality wines; and those from Pauillac age extremely well.

Three of the five first-growths from the 1855 classification of the Médoc are situated in Pauillac: Lafite, Latour, and Mouton-Rothschild.
interesting_facts: Though Pauillac boasts some of Bordeaux's most acclaimed estates, the town itself is very small.
More than half of the 18 classified 'Fifth-Growths' are in Pauillac, including the famous Château Lynch-Bages.

Château Mouton-Rothschild, which encompases 90 hectares (222 acres) in Pauillac was elevated from a 'Second-Growth' to a 'First-Growth in 1973—the only time in the history of the 1855 Classification that a winery's classified position was re-evaluated.

top_list.name: Vivino's 2017 Wine Style Awards: Californian Cabernet Sauvignon

style.name: Malbec (Argentine)
style.description:
Extremely popular, Argentinian Malbec is an inky, medium-bodied, dry red wine with strong impressions of dark fruits on the nose and palate. This wine tends to have mellower tannins than its French counterpart.

Heavily dependent on where they are grown for variations in flavor, Argentinian Malbec has quickly become a world favorite due to the characteristics that the high altitude climate and soils impart to the fruit.

Originally from France, it is one of the original 5 “Bordeaux” grapes. It is scarcely planted in France anymore.

It has found an amazingly hospitable home in the mountains of Argentina from which some of the world's best selling Malbecs are grown.

Starkly different from French versions in structure and flavor, this wine is a good investment for collectors, as the wine can age for several years before drinking.This wine also pairs very well with any savory red meat dish-- particularly dishes that include spice.
interesting_facts: Le jour mondial du Malbec est célébré le 17 avril.
Les cultivateurs investissent des fortunes dans des filets permettant de protéger les vignes de Malbec des tempêtes de la grêle fréquentes en haute altitude.
Des portions importantes de Malbec argentin se développent à des altitudes proches de 1500 mètres (5000 pieds).
Presque tout le Malbec cultivé en France est maintenant utilisé pour le mélange.

top_list.name: Vivino's 2020 Wine Style Awards: Argentinian Malbec

vintage.name: Domaine de La Romanée-Conti La Tâche Grand Cru 2001
Brunelli Campo del Titari Amarone della Valpolicella Classico Riserva 2011

wine.name: Campo del Titari Amarone della Valpolicella Classico Riserva

style.name: Amarone (Italie)
style.description:
L'Amarone della Valpolicella est un vin rouge italien riche et sec de la région de Vénétie. Il est principalement issu du cépage corvina. L'Amarone se caractérise par des saveurs mûres et corsées.

Immédiatement après avoir été récolté, le raisin est mis à sécher à l'air libre. Cette technique, appelée « appassimento » (ou passerillage), permet de concentrer les sucres et les saveurs du raisin pour produire un vin distinctif et corsé, bien adapté au vieillissement.

On dit souvent que vous pouvez « oublier » un Amarone dans votre cave à vin sans vous en soucier. Même les vins Amarone ordinaires peuvent être vieillis pendant 10 à 15 ans. Selon le millésime et la technique de vieillissement, les vins de qualité exceptionnelle peuvent être dégustés jusqu'à 30 à 50 ans après leur mise en bouteille !

Dans le domaine du vin, le temps c'est de l'argent. Le processus de vieillissement, le travail manuel et les vignobles d'exception dont il est issu font de l'Amarone un vin assez onéreux. Généralement, une bouteille de ce vin emblématique est vendue à partir de 50 à 60 dollars, mais son prix peut atteindre des sommets.

Malgré son statut d'icône, l'Amarone n'a reçu l'appellation DOCG (équivalent de l'AOP) qu'en 2009.

En raison de son caractère aromatique puissant, de sa nature robuste et de son degré d'alcool élevé (14 % minimum), l'Amarone se marie de préférence avec des plats aux saveurs très prononcées.
style.blurb: Vin DOGC à base de corvina de Vénétie
interesting_facts: En raison du processus de séchage, l'Amarone nécessite au moins le double de la quantité de raisins pour produire une seule bouteille de vin.
L'Amarone a été inventé par accident au début du 20ème siècle lorsqu'un fût de Recioto, un vin sucré italien, a fermenté plus longtemps que prévu.
En italien, « Amarone » signifie littéralement « le grand amer », ce qui le distingue du vin doux auquel il doit son origine.
Après la production, beaucoup de vignerons utilisent les lies de l'Amarone pour donner plus de profondeur aux vins habituels de Valpolicella, ce qui donne le Valpolicella Ripasso.
Le processus de séchage a été fait traditionnellement sur des nattes de paille. Cependant, c'est un procédé très contrôlé afin de réduire le risque de contamination bactérienne ou fongique.

top_list.name: Vivino's 2019 Wine Style Awards: Italian Amarone
Vivino's 2020 Wine Style Awards: Italian Amarone

style.name: Vin rouge d'Espagne
style.description:
The savory red wines of Spain are brooding and complex. They are typically a little lighter than a California Cabernet, but richer and fuller than a Pinot Noir.

The most commonly used red grapes in Spain are the lovely Tempranillo grape and the rich Garnacha, but Cabernet Sauvignon is starting to get popular as well.

The main grape in Spain is Tempranillo, which is followed closely by Garnacha. In the past, Spanish reds were know to be worthy of aging for decades and were very expensive because of this. Now that technology is more available they are making more affordable, fruitier wines.

The most famous red wine in Spain is Rioja and it is made from the Tempranillo grape. Rioja is usually very complex and savory. Another famous wine is Priorat which is made largely from Garnacha and lush with dark fruit, spice, and vanilla.

Sometimes Rioja and Priorat wines can be very pricey due to their long aging, but often those same wineries make much more affordable wines that are aged for less time, but are still delicious!
style.blurb: Souvent à base de tempranillo
interesting_facts: Spain has the most land dedicated to vineyards of any country in the world!
Spain is known for using American Oak barrels instead of French Oak barrels, because the wood was readily available to them after they started colonizing the new world.
Spanish vineyards are typically planted with the vineyard rows very far apart.
The three categories for how long a Spanish red wine is aged before bottling are the following: Crianza (2 years), Riserva (3 years), and Gran Riserva (5 years).
The two most commonly planted red wine grapes in Spain are Tempranillo and Garnacha.

style.name: Syrah (Californie)
style.description:
Californian Syrah certainly isn't a wine for the meek. This bold, spicy wine typically has heaps of raspberry, black fruit and heady levels of alcohol.

Syrah is relatively new to California, yet it's taken extremely well to the climate. It loves long periods of sunshine, and the heat of the Central Coast AVA.

Originating in the Rhone Valley, Syrah was first planted en masse in California in the 1980s, and the last 25 years have seen production of the grape swell.

Syrah is a suitable wine for those that like their alcohol. It tends to hover around the 14-15% ABV region, and is known for its potent dark fruit and soft fruit. Californian Syrah is a great alternative to Merlot or Cabernet Sauvignon.

San Luis Obispo in the Central Coast is the largest Syrah producing region in the United States. It's high daily temperatures help the grape ripen through the roof and result in high alcohol wines with beautifully concentrated flavor.

Unsurprisingly, this wine needs big, hearty food to keep it in check. Think lamb, venison, winter stews, and any pepper-heavy sauces.
interesting_facts: Syrah was predicted to be the “next big red grape” in the 2000s, though Pinot Noir made a comeback.
The original pioneers of Californian Syrah are known as the Rhone Rangers.
Syrah and the Australian Shiraz are the same grapes with slightly different names.

top_list.name: Vivino's 2018 Wine Style Awards: Californian Syrah
Vivino's 2019 Wine Style Awards: Californian Syrah
Vivino's 2020 Wine Style Awards: Californian Syrah

Immédiatement après avoir été récolté, le raisin est mis à sécher à l'air libre. Cette technique, appelée « appassimento » (ou passerillage), permet de concentrer les sucres et les saveurs du raisin pour produire un vin distinctif et corsé, bien adapté au vieillissement.

On dit souvent que vous pouvez « oublier » un Amarone dans votre cave à vin sans vous en soucier. Même les vins Amarone ordinaires peuvent être vieillis pendant 10 à 15 ans. Selon le millésime et la technique de vieillissement, les vins de qualité exceptionnelle peuvent être dégustés jusqu'à 30 à 50 ans après leur mise en bouteille !

Dans le domaine du vin, le temps c'est de l'argent. Le processus de vieillissement, le travail manuel et les vignobles d'exception dont il est issu font de l'Amarone un vin assez onéreux. Généralement, une bouteille de ce vin emblématique est vendue à partir de 50 à 60 dollars, mais son prix peut atteindre des sommets.

Malgré son statut d'icône, l'Amarone n'a reçu l'appellation DOCG (équivalent de l'AOP) qu'en 2009.

En raison de son caractère aromatique puissant, de sa nature robuste et de son degré d'alcool élevé (14 % minimum), l'Amarone se marie de préférence avec des plats aux saveurs très prononcées.
style.blurb: Vin DOGC à base de corvina de Vénétie
interesting_facts: En raison du processus de séchage, l'Amarone nécessite au moins le double de la quantité de raisins pour produire une seule bouteille de vin.
L'Amarone a été inventé par accident au début du 20ème siècle lorsqu'un fût de Recioto, un vin sucré italien, a fermenté plus longtemps que prévu.
En italien, « Amarone » signifie littéralement « le grand amer », ce qui le distingue du vin doux auquel il doit son origine.
Après la production, beaucoup de vignerons utilisent les lies de l'Amarone pour donner plus de profondeur aux vins habituels de Valpolicella, ce qui donne le Valpolicella Ripasso.
Le processus de séchage a été fait traditionnellement sur des nattes de paille. Cependant, c'est un procédé très contrôlé afin de réduire le risque de contamination bactérienne ou fongique.

top_list.name: Vivino's 2019 Wine Style Awards: Italian Amarone
Vivino's 2020 Wine Style Awards: Italian Amarone

style.name: Vin rouge d'Espagne
style.description:
The savory red wines of Spain are brooding and complex. They are typically a little lighter than a California Cabernet, but richer and fuller than a Pinot Noir.

The most commonly used red grapes in Spain are the lovely Tempranillo grape and the rich Garnacha, but Cabernet Sauvignon is starting to get popular as well.

The main grape in Spain is Tempranillo, which is followed closely by Garnacha. In the past, Spanish reds were know to be worthy of aging for decades and were very expensive because of this. Now that technology is more available they are making more affordable, fruitier wines.

The most famous red wine in Spain is Rioja and it is made from the Tempranillo grape. Rioja is usually very complex and savory. Another famous wine is Priorat which is made largely from Garnacha and lush with dark fruit, spice, and vanilla.

Sometimes Rioja and Priorat wines can be very pricey due to their long aging, but often those same wineries make much more affordable wines that are aged for less time, but are still delicious!
style.blurb: Souvent à base de tempranillo
interesting_facts: Spain has the most land dedicated to vineyards of any country in the world!
Spain is known for using American Oak barrels instead of French Oak barrels, because the wood was readily available to them after they started colonizing the new world.
Spanish vineyards are typically planted with the vineyard rows very far apart.
The three categories for how long a Spanish red wine is aged before bottling are the following: Crianza (2 years), Riserva (3 years), and Gran Riserva (5 years).
The two most commonly planted red wine grapes in Spain are Tempranillo and Garnacha.

style.name: Syrah (Californie)
style.description:
Californian Syrah certainly isn't a wine for the meek. This bold, spicy wine typically has heaps of raspberry, black fruit and heady levels of alcohol.

Syrah is relatively new to California, yet it's taken extremely well to the climate. It loves long periods of sunshine, and the heat of the Central Coast AVA.

Originating in the Rhone Valley, Syrah was first planted en masse in California in the 1980s, and the last 25 years have seen production of the grape swell.

Syrah is a suitable wine for those that like their alcohol. It tends to hover around the 14-15% ABV region, and is known for its potent dark fruit and soft fruit. Californian Syrah is a great alternative to Merlot or Cabernet Sauvignon.

San Luis Obispo in the Central Coast is the largest Syrah producing region in the United States. It's high daily temperatures help the grape ripen through the roof and result in high alcohol wines with beautifully concentrated flavor.

Unsurprisingly, this wine needs big, hearty food to keep it in check. Think lamb, venison, winter stews, and any pepper-heavy sauces.
interesting_facts: Syrah was predicted to be the “next big red grape” in the 2000s, though Pinot Noir made a comeback.
The original pioneers of Californian Syrah are known as the Rhone Rangers.
Syrah and the Australian Shiraz are the same grapes with slightly different names.

style.name: Vin rouge d'Espagne

The most commonly used red grapes in Spain are the lovely Tempranillo grape and the rich Garnacha, but Cabernet Sauvignon is starting to get popular as well.

The main grape in Spain is Tempranillo, which is followed closely by Garnacha. In the past, Spanish reds were know to be worthy of aging for decades and were very expensive because of this. Now that technology is more available they are making more affordable, fruitier wines.

The most famous red wine in Spain is Rioja and it is made from the Tempranillo grape. Rioja is usually very complex and savory. Another famous wine is Priorat which is made largely from Garnacha and lush with dark fruit, spice, and vanilla.

Sometimes Rioja and Priorat wines can be very pricey due to their long aging, but often those same wineries make much more affordable wines that are aged for less time, but are still delicious!

Spain is known for using American Oak barrels instead of French Oak barrels, because the wood was readily available to them after they started colonizing the new world.
Spanish vineyards are typically planted with the vineyard rows very far apart.

The two most commonly planted red wine grapes in Spain are Tempranillo and Garnacha.

style.name: Brunello (Italie)
style.description:
From Tuscany in central Italy, Brunello enjoys a distinction as one of Italy's most favored wines.

Brunello ages well and is great for collecting. The wine is bold, rich, and full-bodied. Red and black fruit assertively grace the nose and palate.

Brunello is made totally from Sangiovese grapes that take on the characteristics of the soil, vegetation and climate of the region in which it is grown.

Layered aromas and velvety tannins complement medium-high acidity. Consider decanting this wine to enjoy its full complexity.

This wine pairs well with big protein ladened dishes. You may also enjoy it with salted cheeses and cured meats. Try to avoid pairing with dishes where the wine would overwhelm flavors, such as leafy greens and subtly seasoned meats.
style.blurb: Vin DOCG sangiovese de Toscane
interesting_facts: L'appellation Brunello compte moins de 10 vignerons dans toute l'Italie. Il y a pourtant des vingtaines de domaines sur une aire géographique très restreinte.
La loi italienne interdit toute intervention visant à modifier la température au cours de la croissance du Brunello.
Le Brunello est fait à partir d'un cépage particulier, le Sangiovese, aussi utilisé pour faire le Chianti.

vintage.name: Dal Forno Romano Amarone della Valpolicella Monte Lodoletta 2003

style.name: Amarone (Italie)
style.description:
L'Amarone della Valpolicella est un vin rouge italien riche et sec de la région de Vénétie. Il est principalement issu du cépage corvina. L'Amarone se caractérise par des saveurs mûres et corsées.

Immédiatement après avoir été récolté, le raisin est mis à sécher à l'air libre. Cette technique, appelée « appassimento » (ou passerillage), permet de concentrer les sucres et les saveurs du raisin pour produire un vin distinctif et corsé, bien adapté au vieillissement.

Généralement, une bouteille de ce vin emblématique est vendue à partir de 50 à 60 dollars, mais son prix peut atteindre des sommets.

Malgré son statut d'icône, l'Amarone n'a reçu l'appellation DOCG (équivalent de l'AOP) qu'en 2009.
